details.title: A New Method for Goodness-of-Fit Testing Based on Type-II Right Censored Samples

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math., Tamkang Univ., Tamkang

p: Chien-Tai Lin is a Professor in the Department of Mathematics, Tamkang University, Tamsui, Taiwan. She received her Ph.D. in 1993 from Florida State University, Tallahassee. She has been at Tamkang University since 1993. Her research interests include reliability, and applications of linear combinations of spacings.

authors.name: Chien-Tai Lin

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math., Tamkang Univ., Tamkang

p: Yen-Lung Huang is a Ph.D. student in the Department of Mathematics, Tamkang University, Tamsui, Taiwan. His research interests include reliability, and statistical inference.

authors.name: Yen-Lung Huang

p: N. Balakrishnan is a Professor in the Department of Mathematics & Statistics, McMaster University, Hamilton, Canada. He received his Ph.D. in 1981 from the Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, India. He has been at McMaster University since 1985. His research interests include order statistics, statistical inference, and distribution theory. He is a Fellow of the American Statistical Association, and currently is the Editor-in-Chief for Communications in Statistics, Journal of Statistical Planning and Inference, and the Encyclopedia of Statistical Sciences.

details.abstract: We present a simple method for testing goodness-of-fit based on type-II right censored samples. Applying the property of order statistics due to Malmquist, we can transform any conventional type-II right censored sample of size r out of n from a uniform distribution to a complete sample of size r from a uniform distribution. This result is used to develop the proposed goodness-of-fit test procedure. The simulation studies reveal that the proposed approach provides as good or better overall power than the method of Michael & Schucany.

references.title:
On a property of order statistics from a
rectangular distribution

context.text: In this work, we propose a different method for the same problem based on Malmquist's result [1].
Section III describes the method of [2], and the proposed method based on a result of [1].
The proof of Theorem 2 can be found in [1]; see also [5], pp. 79-80, [6], pp. 18, and [7], pp. 33.

references.text: S. Malmquist, "On a property of order statistics from a rectangular distribution", Skandinavisk Aktuarietidskrift, vol. 33, pp. 214-222, 1950.

references.title:
A new approach to testing goodness
of fit for censored samples

context.text: Because of the limited applicability of the asymptotic results, and the restriction due to the form of censoring, Michael & Schucany [2] suggested a method of transforming a censored sample of size \$r\$ out of \$n\$ from a uniform distribution to a complete sample of size \$r\$ from a uniform distribution.
The proposed method is very simple, and easy to apply; and it is computationally less involved than the method of [2].
Moreover, Monte Carlo simulations reveal that the proposed method provides as good or better power than Michael & Schucany's method [2].
Section III describes the method of [2], and the proposed method based on a result of [1].

In Section IV, two extensive Monte Carlo simulation studies are carried out to examine the power properties of both methods, as well as other known methods discussed in [2]–
[4].
In this section, we will first state the main idea underlying the transformation of [2], and our method; and then we will describe the associated algorithms for each method.
From the properties of uniform order statistics in Section II, Michael & Schucany [2] established the following theorem:.

To compare the proposed approach with Michael & Schucany's method [2], an empirical power study similar to Table 2 of [2] has been carried out using the following models: (i) 8 power function [or Beta \$(a,1)\$] distributions, (ii) 8 reversed power function [or Beta \$(1,a)\$] distributions, where \$a=1/2\$, 1/3, 1/4, 1/5, 2, 3, 4, 5, and (iii) two non-uniform distributions, \$F_{41}\$, and \$F_{51}\$, mentioned in [2], and [8].
The Anderson-Darling statistics computed on the transformed sample using the technique of [2], and the proposed method are denoted by TAr2, and T*Ar2, respectively.

Using the approach of [2], they are computed as follows.

1)Compute the MLE \$\hat{\theta}\$ of a \$p\$-dimensional real vector \$\theta\$ from the observed Type-II right censored sample \$x_{1}<\cdots<x_{r}\$.
2)Calculate \$v_{i}=F(x_{i};\hat{\theta})\$, and convert the censored sample \$v_{i}\$ to a complete sample of size \$r,\,v_{1}^{\ast},\ldots,v_{r}^{\ast}\$.
3)Compute \$y_{i}=\Phi^{-1}(v_{i}^{\ast})\$, where \$\Phi^{-1}\$ is the inverse cumulative distribution function of the standard normal distribution.
4)Compute \$u_{i}=\Phi\{(y_{i}-\bar{y})/s_{y}\}\$, where \$\bar{y}=\sum_{i=1}^{r}y_{i}/r\$, and \$s_{y}^{2}=\sum_{i=1}^{r}(y_{i}-\bar{y})^{2}/(r-1)\$.
5)Calculate the Cramér-von Mises statistic, and Anderson-Darling statistic, respectively \$W^{2}\$, and \$A^{2}\$, where
6)Calculate the modified statistics .

To test that these times-to-failure are exponentially distributed with parameter 10 (mean time-to-failure as 10 hours), Michael & Schucany [2] reported the statistic TAr2, evaluating from the transformed censored sample, as 3.404, which exceeds the 0.025 critical value of 3.070.
The method is computationally simple, and provides as good or better overall power than the method of [2].

references.text: J. R. Michael, W. R. Schucany, "A new approach to testing goodness of fit for censored samples", Technometrics, vol. 21, pp. 435-441, 1979.

references.title: Goodness-of-Fit Techniques

context.text: Several authors have investigated goodness of fit tests based on empirical distribution functions (EDF) with Type-II censored samples for parametric distributions; see [3] for a general discussion.

In Section IV, two extensive Monte Carlo simulation studies are carried out to examine the power properties of both methods, as well as other known methods discussed in [2]–[3]
[4].

The first seven statistics include a modified Kolmogorov-Smirnov statistic a statistic which is based on the sum of squared spacings between adjacent order statistics a modified correlation test statistic and the following modified Cramér-von Mises type statistics:

(I)the modified Cramér-von Mises type statistics 
(II)the modified Anderson-Darling statistic 
(III)the modified Watson statistic 
Details of all these statistics can be found in the works of [9]–

[12], and the book by [3].
To assess the performance of these statistics, we also computed the Cramér-von Mises statistic 2Wr,n2, and Anderson-Darling statistic 2Ar,n2 in [3], and [12] for the Type-II censored data.

Under different censoring levels, D'Agostino & Stephens [3] presented some critical values of 2Wr,n2, and 2Ar,n2 for testing for exponential, and standard normal distributions with unknown parameter(s).

references.text: R. B. D'Agostino, M. A. Stephens, Goodness-of-Fit Techniques, 1986, Marcel Dekker.

references.title:
A
general purpose approximate goodness-of-fit test

context.text:
In Section IV, two extensive Monte Carlo simulation studies are carried out to examine the power properties of both methods, as well as other known methods discussed in [2]–
[4].
The statistics used here are the modified Cramér-von Mises statistic, and Anderson-Darling statistic discussed in [4].
The critical values of the modified test statistics can be found in Table 1 of [4].

references.text: G. Chen, N. Balakrishnan, "A general purpose approximate goodness-of-fit test", Journal of Quality Technology, vol. 27, pp. 154-161, 1995.

references.title: A First Course in Order Statistics

context.text:
These order statistics have well known properties listed below; see, for example, [5], and [6].

(I)\$U_{i:n}\$ has a Beta \$(i,n-i+1)\$ distribution for \$1\leq i\leq n\$.
(II)The random variables \$(U_{i_{1}:n}/U_{i_{2}:n}),(U_{i_{2}:n}/U_{i_{3}:n}),\ldots,(U_{i_{\ell-1}:n}/U_{i_{\ell}:n}),U_{i_{\ell}:n} (1\leq i_{1}<i_{2}<\cdots<i_{\ell}\leq n)\$ are all \$s\$-independent, having the distributions Beta \$(i_{1},i_{2}-i_{1})\$, Beta \$(i_{2},i_{3}-i_{2}),\ldots\$, Beta \$(i_{\ell-1},i_{\ell}-i_{\ell-1})\$, and Beta \$(i_{\ell},n-i_{\ell}+1)\$, respectively.
(III)For \$1<r<n\$, the random variables \$(U_{i:n}/U_{r:n}),\,i=1,2,\ldots,r-1\$, are distributed like an ordered random sample of size \$r-1\$ from the uniform (0, 1) distribution, and the random variables \$(U_{j:n}-U_{r:n}/1-U_{r:n}),\,j=r+1,r+2,\ldots,n\$, are distributed like an ordered random sample of size \$n-r\$ from the uniform (0, 1) distribution.
The proof of Theorem 2 can be found in [1]; see also [5], pp. 79-80, [6], pp. 18, and [7], pp. 33.

references.text: B. C. Arnold, N. Balakrishnan, H. N. Nagaraja, A First Course in Order Statistics, 1992, John Wiley & Sons.

references.title: Order Statistics

context.text:
These order statistics have well known properties listed below; see, for example, [5], and [6].

(I)\$U_{i:n}\$ has a Beta \$(i,n-i+1)\$ distribution for \$1\leq i\leq n\$.
(II)The random variables \$(U_{i_{1}:n}/U_{i_{2}:n}),(U_{i_{2}:n}/U_{i_{3}:n}),\ldots,(U_{i_{\ell-1}:n}/U_{i_{\ell}:n}),U_{i_{\ell}:n} (1\leq i_{1}<i_{2}<\cdots<i_{\ell}\leq n)\$ are all \$s\$-independent, having the distributions Beta \$(i_{1},i_{2}-i_{1})\$, Beta \$(i_{2},i_{3}-i_{2}),\ldots\$, Beta \$(i_{\ell-1},i_{\ell}-i_{\ell-1})\$, and Beta \$(i_{\ell},n-i_{\ell}+1)\$, respectively.
(III)For \$1<r<n\$, the random variables \$(U_{i:n}/U_{r:n}),\,i=1,2,\ldots,r-1\$, are distributed like an ordered random sample of size \$r-1\$ from the uniform (0, 1) distribution, and the random variables \$(U_{j:n}-U_{r:n}/1-U_{r:n}),\,j=r+1,r+2,\ldots,n\$, are distributed like an ordered random sample of size \$n-r\$ from the uniform (0, 1) distribution.
The proof of Theorem 2 can be found in [1]; see also [5], pp. 79-80, [6], pp. 18, and [7], pp. 33.

references.text: H. A. David, H. N. Nagaraja, Order Statistics, 2003, John Wiley & Sons.

references.title: Order Statistics and Inference: Estimation Methods

context.text: The proof of Theorem 2 can be found in [1]; see also [5], pp. 79-80, [6], pp. 18, and [7], pp. 33.

references.text: N. Balakrishnan, A. C. Cohen, Order Statistics and Inference: Estimation Methods, 1991, Academic Press.

references.title: Power studies of some tests for uniformity

context.text: To compare the proposed approach with Michael & Schucany's method [2], an empirical power study similar to Table 2 of [2] has been carried out using the following models: (i) 8 power function [or Beta \$(a,1)\$] distributions, (ii) 8 reversed power function [or Beta \$(1,a)\$] distributions, where \$a=1/2\$, 1/3, 1/4, 1/5, 2, 3, 4, 5, and (iii) two non-uniform distributions, \$F_{41}\$, and \$F_{51}\$, mentioned in [2], and [8].

references.text: C. P. Quesenberry, F. L. Miller, "Power studies of some tests for uniformity", Journal of Statistical Computation and Simulation, vol. 5, pp. 169-191, 1977.

references.title:
A Kolmogorov-Smirnov test for
censored samples

context.text:
The first seven statistics include a modified Kolmogorov-Smirnov statistic a statistic which is based on the sum of squared spacings between adjacent order statistics a modified correlation test statistic and the following modified Cramér-von Mises type statistics:

(I)the modified Cramér-von Mises type statistics 
(II)the modified Anderson-Darling statistic 
(III)the modified Watson statistic 
Details of all these statistics can be found in the works of [9]–

[12], and the book by [3].
Barr & Davidson [9] considered \$n=20\$ items on a reliability test, and recorded the first 7 failure times (in hours) as 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4, 0.7, 1.0, and 1.4.

references.text: D. R. Barr, T. Davidson, "A Kolmogorov-Smirnov test for censored samples", Technometrics, vol. 15, pp. 739-757, 1973.

context.text: Data taken from [14], pp. 420 are used here to make a comparison of all the test statistics discussed earlier in Section IV.
